notesStmt.note: Le Chevalier Soleie is one the most famous plays by Pierre-Paul Pint, a puppeteer from Liège. It is typical of the chivalric repertory of traditional shows from Wallonia (Belgium) and the North of France. The theme could be remotely inspired by Pedro Hernández de Villaumbrales’ Cabellero del Sol (1552), which Pinet may have known from the French adaption by the Comte de Tressan. However, it is handled on the mode of parody here. In his presentation, the author explains that the play “where nothing offenses morals, can be played on a chair or a table, in houses or cabarets, with handkerchiefs of different colours. Tie a knot at the top of a handkerchief, leaving a bit of tissue to hold it by.” The printed booklet is kept in the Museum of Walloon Life in Liège.

normalization.p: The semi-diplomatic norms applied are intended to guide and facilitate the reading of the original texts. The transcriptions therefore include spelling and grammatical corrections according to current standards.
The author's orthographic and grammatical corrections have been integrated into the text without being marked. Cuts for performance purposes have not been adopted in the transcription.
Syntax has been modernised where it is naturally incorrect or has become incomprehensible today. Additions are limited and indicated by square brackets.
The copyist's obvious errors (scene numbers, character attributions, etc.) have been corrected. The list of characters could also be corrected.

punctuation.p: Punctuation has been corrected according to modern rules.

projectDesc.p: Text collected during the PuppetPlays project funded by European Union (Grant Agreement 835193) under Horizon 2020. The PuppetPlays project aims to re-evaluate the contribution of the puppets repertoire to the construction of European cultural identity. Its main goals is to collect a corpus of representative plays from Western Europe (Germany, Austria, Belgium, Spain, France, Great Britain, Italy, Netherlands, Portugal, Switzerland) between the 17th and the 21th century. It also tries to identify the characteristics of puppet dramaturgy and their variations depending on eras, cultural spheres, producing conditions, and the aimed public.
This edition is the result of university research work, reviewed by the principal investigator.

docTitle.titlePart: Histoire comique en vers pour théâtre et marionnettes

set.p: Cette pièce, où rien ne froisse la morale, peut se jouer sur une chaise ou sur une table, dans les ménages ou dans les cabarets, avec des mouchoirs de poche de différentes couleurs. Faire un nœud sur le haut du mouchoir, laisser dépasser un petit bout pour le maintenir.

Monsieur Pierre-Paul PINET, directeur du Théâtre de marionnettes, donne des représentations dans les maisons riches. Il a joué au Café des Milles Colonnes, dit Cabaret wallon, au profit du monument Defrêcheux ; il est possesseur de sept diplômes et six médailles qu’il a obtenu à l’Exposition de marionnettes au Vieux-Liège, rue Feronstrée ; il est surnommé Artiste pour ses ouvrages montés dans des bouteilles. Il est né à Liège en 1852 et est l’auteur des « Råskignou lidjwès » et de plusieurs pièces wallonnes.
Pour tous renseignements, s’adresser à l’auteur, rue Devant les Écoliers, 22 (Cour Falla), Liège.
